newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Islamic law hits Grozny as rebels tighten grip.
newsitem.headline: Islamic law hits Grozny as rebels tighten grip.

text.p: Chechen separatist rebels, applying strict Islamic law, carried out judicial beatings for drunks on Wednesday as they tightened their grip on the regional capital.

After a brief recitation of the crime and sentence, a sweating, bearded fighter, draped in ammunition belts and wearing a headband carrying an excerpt from the Koran, brought down a short, stout club with a dull smack on the backs and legs of the first of five offenders.
Such beatings have become common practice in Grozny as the Moslem independence fighters stamp their mark on the city they seized from the Russian army in fierce fighting last month.

The five punished on Wednesday were beaten on a rough wooden bench in front of curious onlookers in the courtyard of the local headquarters of one of the joint Russian-Chechen police patrols established in the city under a ceasefire agreed by Kremlin envoy Alexander Lebed.
Each received 40 blows for being found drunk in a public place. Most squirmed and squealed, but clung to the bench as the baton rained down blows. But for the last man it was too much.
He shouted in pain and gradually wriggled off the bench.
His punishment was stopped so, his jailers said, he would not be humiliated before the crowd.
"Sharia law is the most just law," said one Chechen fighter after the beatings. He refused to give his name, calling himself "a son of Allah, a fighter for Islam and a son of the Caucasus".
"I am punished because I have sinned and need to be punished," he quoted from a religious text.
Punishments under sharia law have been common in rebel-held villages but are a new phenomenon in Grozny.
The rebels have been tightening their grip on the capital, taking control of day-to-day matters.

Many local people now automatically head for the separatist forces' main headquarters in a central sports stadium to seek help and advice as they rebuild their homes and their lives after the fortnight of heavy fighting that broke out on August 6 when the rebels attacked Russian posts.

The agreement signed on Saturday by Kremlin envoy Lebed and rebel chief-of-staff Aslan Maskhadov provided for a joint commission to be set up by October 1 to monitor the pullout of troops and oversee the economic reconstruction of the region after nearly 21 months of war.
But it is vague about the political arrangements and the rebels are filling the power vacuum.
Several Chechens, unused to strict Moslem observances after seven decades of Soviet communist atheism, said their region was unlikely to become a stronghold of Islamic fundamentalism.
Application of sharia law in Grozny has so far been limited to beatings for drunkenness and sometimes theft.
The sale of alcohol has also been banned.
At least one Chechen fighter, however, said he wanted sharia law extended. "If someone kills or rapes then that person will be killed," he said.
Russian soldiers watching the beatings on Wednesday seemed bemused by what they were witnessing but accepted it.
"Seeing it for the first time it looks mad. But it's normal, it's the only way to get rid of and punish alcoholism," said Lieutenant Nikolai Kotosonov.
Others seemed to agree with the need for tough laws after the disruptions caused by war and rebellion.
"I would rather starve to death than sell alcohol," said one woman trader at a row of roadside stalls. "Of course, I will live under sharia. It will bring law and order."
